heisigComment: * When this character is used as a primitive in its full form, we keep the key-word sense of a portent. When it appears to the left in its abbreviated form (namely, the left half only), we shall give it the pictographic sense of a turtle.
heisigStory: Here we have a pictograph of the back of a turtle, the two sloping vertical strokes representing the central ridge and the four short strokes the pattern. Think of reading turtle shells as a way to foretell the future, and in particular things that portend coming evils.
koohiiStory1: When your wife´s LEGs get huge hairs on them it is surely a bad portent for things to come.
koohiiStory2: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.
readingExamples: 兆し (きざ.し), 兆す (きざ.す)
